narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Knowledge: society, culture, music, and gender in the Regency period; how sexism manifested then; knowledge of Austen's novels 
Skills: how to write interdisciplinary papers that consider music, culture, and literature; how to engage with secondary sources; how to write about sound

I came into this class with no knowledge of classical music but a deep love of Jane Austen. After finishing the course, I will never view the novels, musical practice, film scores, or gender roles the same way again. This class is a revelation.

This course focused on music in Jane Austen novels but also encompassed so much more. Music was the medium through which we discussed the social and cultural norms of Regency Era England, talked about character and plot development, and examined more complex themes. It was a great way to also think about late 17th to mid-18th century composers and the music Austen herself would have consumed.
An awesome span of Jane Austen's novels through the lens of music, as well as other source and secondary texts on women at the time (music, arts, domesticity, family, etc.)
I enjoyed the lively discussions we had in this class and learned how to convey my thoughts in an effective and efficient way.

We discussed music as an accomplishment in the time of Jane Austen and her characters in her novels. Most of what was discussed I knew but having a class to deep dive into discussions about these topics was definitely interesting.
I learned a lot about the importance of music in Regency Era England, and how music was import in Jane Austen's personal life and novels.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
This course was truly incredible.  The workload was good, and I was always excited to do work on readings and assignments for this class. 
I loved the progression from historical context, to the novels themselves, to how the novels have been adapted.   

Possible improvements: there probably isn't time to add another novel (the course is very well-paced), but that would be fun.  Also, I loved discussing clips in class, but since not everyone had seen every adaptation, I think it would be beneficial to also choose one adaptation to dive into more deeply.  Everyone could watch it and then analyze it more closely in class.  Last, it would be great to spend more time analyzing the music itself, whether adaptation soundtracks or Austen's collection.

Strengths: fascinating subject matter, wonderful professor, very involved discussions, lots of freedom with assignments, manageable courseload
Weaknesses: none

The assignments were fun and engaging. The readings were always manageable, and the secondary readings always added to the week's topic. Seminar was also always enjoyable as it was a good mix of discussion, text analysis, and then visual/auditory elements.

Strengths amazing discussions!!! A really engaging subject matter that still relates to modern day.
Weaknesses none!

The strength of this course was the ability to freely discuss our thoughts and ideas about the course materials. This might also be a weakness of the course as it does not allow for a multi-faceted approach to learning the material, but I didn't mind.

A weakness would definitely be the fact that it was over zoom. Definitely gave students an opportunity to disengage. However, the professor asked very thought-provoking questions and kept the course very interesting.
Strengths: Class content and readings are interesting, assignments allow creativity and are fun to complete.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We used breakout rooms occasionally, which was great, and I wished we had used them more.  I was also really grateful for the 5 minute breaks halfway through class to help reduce Zoom fatigue.
The short break in the middle was great a nice refresh before we shifted gears in the second half of class.
I thought this course dealt really well with the challenges presented from COVID-19 and we had interesting topics of discussion despite the inevitable disconnected feeling of Zoom.
I really appreciated the breaks in the middle of class to combat zoom fatigue.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes!  I cannot rave about this course enough.  If you love music and/or Jane Austen (and I love both), you should definitely take this course, because what you learn is fascinating.  I looked forward to class every week because it was so fun to escape into the world of Austen.  Then after each seminar, I would tell anyone who would listen about how much I loved the course.  The topics and assignments were creative, worthwhile, and genuinely exciting.  Also, Professor Peritz is so engaging, kind, and understanding.
Take this class. You will love it

Yes, the course was a fantastic humanities course. Even if you don't have a strong musical background, you should still take the course. It shows how literature, music, art, and other humanities disciplines can be combined, resulting in really rich discussions on contemporary and historical issues. I loved getting to read Austen novels with a completely new perspective that made me appreciate them all the more. Plus, Professor Pertiz is fantastic.

Yes!! It was a fun and engaging introduction to music theory using Jane Austen's most famous novels and somehow also managed to remain culturally relevant and interesting. Overall a great course, exciting even for those without a musical background.
Yes! It was an excellent seminar, even online. I looked forward to reading the novels every week, and gained insight into female musicality during the Regency era.
In a heartbeat! It's fun to time travel to the 1800s with Jane Austen... and the subject matter sparks some really powerful discussions.
Yes! This class was extremely thought-provoking and informative and I thoroughly enjoyed the combination of interests represented in the class.

Absolutely. This course was extremely interesting. Such a nice group of people. The class size was small enough where I knew every face on the computer and allowed for the professor to check in on each of us to give feedback. Not a ton of work to do in this class but the readings and discussion topics were engaging.
Yes, take this if you want to look at Austen's novels from a different perspective!
